questions.text: A 47- year- old female presented with clinically palpable lymph nodes and no palpable breast mass. Mammogram revealed a mass of 1 cm on the right inner quadrant. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy revealed no axillary involvement. What is the appropriate management of this patient?
questions.explanation:

Sentinel node biopsy If FNAB does not confirm axillary metastasis , patients can proceed to sentinel node surgery for staging .

questions.text: A 38- year- old female was diagnosed with lobular Carcinoma of the right breast with a mass of 3cm on the lower outer quadrant with no lymph node involvement. Which of the following can be done for effective local control of Cancer?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mastectomy and SLND For patients with T1N0 or T2N0 breast cancer, mastectomy and SLND provide effective local control, and radiation therapy is not required.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: C. Post-mastectomy radiation therapy is required only for selected patients with stage II disease, such as patients with extracapsular extension, lymphovascular invasion, age 40 years or younger, close/positive surgical margins, or a nodal positivity ratio (ratio of positive nodes to total nodes examined) of 20% or greater and patients who have undergone less than a standard level I or level II axillary dissection. Option: D. NACT is not indicated for stage II disease

questions.text: A 35- year- old female has a staging of T1N1Mx for breast cancer. A sentinel lymph node biopsy was planned. What is the most commonly used dye in Sentinal Sentinel lymph node biopsy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isophane blue Isophane blue (Lymphazurin) is the most commonly used plain dye. Lymphatic mapping can be performed with a combination of 99mTc-labeled sulfur colloid and Isophane blue (Lymphazurin). Studies indicate that the combination technique may yield the lowest possible false-negative rate. Tc-99 colloid sulphur and Antimony are radioisotopes used.

questions.text: A 54- year- old woman was diagnosed with inoperable breast cancer, stage IIIB. What is the best mode of treatment for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Trastuzumab and pertuzumab can be combined with chemotherapy

options.label: B
options.text: Mastectomy or lumpectomy with axillary lymph node dissection

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neoadjuvant chemotherapy Current NCCN recommendations for treatment of inoperable locally advanced breast cancer are neoadjuvant chemotherapy with an anthracycline-containing or taxane-containing regimen or both , followed by mastectomy or lumpectomy (Option B)with axillary lymph node dissection if necessary, followed by adjuvant radiation therapy(Option D).

Highyeild:

NACT (neoadjuvant chemotherapy) is used for the following indications: Locally advanced breast cancer with T3, T4/N2, and N3 disease to shrink the tumor. Early breast cancer, in exceptional cases, makes it easier to perform breast conservation surgery (BCS). HER2/neu-positive tumors and triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). Premenopausal women (age <50 years). Patients with axillary node metastasis. For patients with HER2-positive breast cancer , trastuzumab and pertuzumab can be combined with chemotherapy in the preoperative setting to increase pathologic complete response rates. For inoperable stage IIIA and stage IIIB breast cancer, neoadjuvant chemotherapy decreases the burden of local-regional cancer. This may permit subsequent modified radical or radical mastectomy, followed by adjuvant radiation therapy.
